Elliotte,

The defect is that implementations of IMoney are supposed to be immutable
and appendTo() allows callers to side effect the parameter. Fixing it
"properly", however, would require a private interface or an abstract class,
neither of which seem warranted to me in this situation. 

I'm interested in the tool that discovered the defect. Does anyone have more
information?

> I'm not sure I understand the actual bug here. (Does anyone 
> have a URL 
> for the actual description of the bug, not just the 
> newsgroup?) but the 
> fix smells pretty bad to me. Most Java code exposes far more 
> methods as 
> public than it should. If indeed this method should not be 
> part of the 
> API, then it should not be public. Documenting that it 
> shouldn't be used 
> is an inadequate response.
> 
> Often overuse of public reflects a failure to use package protected 
> methods, often because the application has been divided into packages 
> and yet the subpackages need to be able to access the 
> internal parts of 
> the superpackages. Possibly Java 6 will fix this at a language level. 
> Until this is fixed most applications and libraries should 
> use a single 
> package, even if that package ends up containing a rather 
> large number 
> of classes.
> 
> Another common problem is the tendency of many programmers 
> and tools to 
> make methods public by default. Conservative design dictates that 
> methods should start their lives with the most restrictive access 
> possible. If a need is discovered to make a private method public, 
> that's easy to change. The reverse operation can be impossible though.
>
